sen.j: 民家（みんか）とは、一般の庶民が暮らす住まいのこと。
sen.e: Minka are residences where ordinary people lived.
Minka are residences where ordinary people lived.
Minka are residences where ordinary people lived.

sen.j: 支配階級、上層階級の住まいに対比して用いられる言葉。
sen.e: This word is used in contrast to mansions where people of ruling classes or higher classes lived.
This word is used in contrast to the large residences where people of ruling classes or higher classes lived.
sen.cmt: I'm not sure 'mansion' is appropriate here - perhaps something along the lines of 'the large residences'.
sen.e: This word is used in contrast to the large residences where people of ruling classes or higher classes lived.

sen.j: 本項では日本の民家について詳述する。
sen.e: This section describes details of minka in Japan.
This article describes the details of minka in Japan.
sen.cmt: Is 'article' perhaps a better word to describle one section of Wikipedia?
sen.e: This section describes the details of minka in Japan.
sen.cmt: 独立した文章ではなく大きな文章の中の「項」であるから、”article”ではなく →”section”

sen.j: 日本建築史や民俗学では、主に江戸時代の農家、町家の類を民家という。
sen.e: Noka (farm house) and machiya (town house) in Edo Period are called minka in architectural history of Janan or in ethnology.
Noka (farm houses) and machiya (town houses) in the Edo Period are called minka in the architectural history of Japan and in ethnology.
sen.cmt: I think the plural is preferable here.
sen.e: Noka (farm houses) and machiya (town houses) in the Edo Period are called minka in the architectural history of Japan and in ethnology.

sen.j: 明治時代以降に建立された住宅で、伝統的様式・技法を用いたものもこれに含まれる。
sen.e: Residential houses that have been built since Meiji Period with traditional designs and construction methods are also included in this type.
The residential houses that have been built since the Meiji Period using traditional designs and construction methods are also included in this type of dwelling.
sen.cmt: Periods in history are given the article 'the'.
sen.e: The residential houses that have been built since the Meiji Period using traditional designs and construction methods are also included in this type of dwelling.

sen.j: また、中・下層の武士の住まいも農家と同様の技法が用いられているものは民家に含める。
sen.e: Houses for middle or lower ranked samurai are also minka if they were built in the same manner as noka.
Houses for middle or lower ranked samurai are also minka if they were built in the same manner as noka.
Houses for middle or lower ranked samurai are also minka if they were built in the same manner as noka.

sen.j: （本項で詳述）
sen.e: (This is described in this section in detail.)
(This is described in this article in detail.)
sen.cmt: This sentence may not be necessary, as this would be expected.
sen.e: (This is described in this section in detail.)
sen.cmt: 独立した文章ではなく大きな文章の中の「項」であるから、”article”ではなく →”section”

sen.j: 現代日本語では、団地やマンションなどの集合住宅に対して、一戸建ての比較的小規模な住宅を指して「民家」と呼ぶことがある。
sen.e: In the modern Japanese language, relatively small sized detached houses are called "minka" to distinguish them from collective housings such as in a housing complex and condominiums.
In the modern Japanese language, relatively small sized detached houses are called "minka" to distinguish them from collective housing such as housing complexes and condominiums.
In the modern Japanese language, relatively small sized detached houses are called 'minka' to distinguish them from collective housing such as housing complexes and condominiums.

sen.j: 特に報道文などで「土砂崩れで民家が押し流され」などと使う。
sen.e: Epecially news reporters ofren use this word as in "a landslide carried minka away."
Especially news reporters often use this word, as in "a landslide carried minka away."
Especially news reporters often use this word, as in 'a landslide carried minka away.'

sen.j: 民家（みんか）とは、一般の庶民が暮らす住まいのことだが、特に建築史や民俗学で、伝統的な様式で造られた農家、町家の類を指す（年代の古いものは古民家とも）。
sen.e: Minka are houses of ordinary people, but especially in architectural history or in ethnology, minka means noka or machiya that are built with traditional designs (old ones are also called kominka).

Minka are houses lived in by ordinary people, but in architectural history or in ethnology, minka means noka or machiya that are built with traditional designs (old ones are also called kominka) in particular.
sen.cmt: 「of」→「lived in by」,「especially」→「in particular」, 「in particular」箇所異動
sen.e: Minka are houses lived in by ordinary people, but in architectural history or in ethnology, minka means noka or machiya that are built with traditional designs (old ones are also called kominka) in particular.

sen.j: 民家には建設された当時の生活状況が反映されており、生業（農業、商業など）や伝統行事と結び付いた要素が多く見られる。
sen.e: Minka reflect elements of lifestyles when they were built, which were closely connected with work (farming or commerce) and traditional events.
In the way they were built minka reflected aspects of lifestyle, being closely linked to work (farming or commerce) and traditional events.
In the way they were built minka reflected aspects of lifestyle, being closely linked to work (farming or commerce) and traditional events.

sen.j: 民家を見る際には、生業や生活との関連から見ていくと、古人の暮らしに根付いた知恵に気付かされることが多い。
sen.e: If you study minka from an aspect of work and life, you often notice ancient people's wisdom rooted in their lives.
Studying minka from the perspective of work and lifestyle, one is struck by the wisdom of ancient people rooted in their lives.
sen.cmt: I think as it is common for people to notice, we should avoid 'you'. This sentence is difficult to render in English naturally.再構成しました。
sen.e: Studying minka from the perspective of work and lifestyle, one is struck by what these reveal about the wisdom of ancient people.
sen.cmt: I have incorporated the feedback but changed "they reveal" to "these reveal" because otherwise it is unclear whether "they" is referring to the minka (which I assume it is not supposed to refer to) or the work and lifestyle of the minka (which I assume it is supposed to refer to).

sen.j: また、民家には地域差があり、それぞれの地方ごとの特色が表れる。
sen.e: Minka are different region to region, showing characteristics of each region.
Minka vary from region to region, showing particular characteristics in each area.
sen.cmt: I think it is best to avoid using 'region' twice if possible.
sen.e: Minka vary from region to region, showing particular characteristics in each area.

sen.j: 近年では、対象となる年代も広がり、明治・大正・昭和戦前期の建物まで、調査研究が行われることがある。
sen.e: In recent years, research and study of minka have extended their subjects to houses of Meiji, Taisho, and Showa Era before the war.
In recent years, the research and study of minka has extended to include the houses of the Meiji, Taisho, and early Showa Eras.
sen.cmt: Their subjects' is clear from the context I think. "Before the war' if used may need clarification - i.e. 'before the Second World War'.
sen.e: In recent years, the research and study of minka has extended to include the houses of the Meiji, Taisho, and early Showa Eras.

sen.j: 民家は生活に密着したものであり、今日まで残された民家は時々の必要に応じた増改築が行われているのが普通である。
sen.e: Minka are closely connected to everyday life, so many minka that have survived to today have been extended or reconstructed as required by necessities then.
Minka are closely connected to everyday life, so many minka that have survived to today have been extended or reconstructed as required at the time.
Minka are closely connected to everyday life, so many minka that have survived to today have been extended or reconstructed as was required at the time.
sen.cmt: 文法間違い。 “as required ”=> “as was required ”

sen.j: 特に文化財的価値があって保存措置が講じられる場合は、当初の状態に復元するのが一般的である。
sen.e: If one of minka has cultural values to be preserved, generally it will be restored to its original state when it was built.
If a minka has cultural value and is to be preserved, generally it will be restored to its original state when it was built.
If a minka has cultural value and is to be preserved, generally it will be restored to its original state when it was built.

sen.j: （これに対して、生きた民家は変化するものであり、そうした変化自体が一つの歴史を物語るものだ、という意見もある）
sen.e: (In contrast, some people say minka are alive and change, and those changes themselves show their history.)
(In contrast, some people say minka are alive and change, and those changes themselves show their history.)
(In contrast, some people say minka are alive and change, and those changes themselves show their history.)

sen.j: 現在日本に残る最も古い民家と考えられるのは、いずれも兵庫県に所在する箱木家と古井家で、既に江戸時代から「千年家」（せんねんや、千年前の家）と呼ばれていた。
sen.e: The oldest minka in Japan are houses of the HAKOI family and the FURUI family both in Hyoto Prefecture, and they had already been called "Sennenya" (a thousand year old house) in Edo Period.

The oldest minka in Japan are the houses of the HAKOI family and the FURUI family, both in Hyoto Prefecture, and they were already being called "Sennenya" (a thousand year old house) in the Edo Period.

The oldest minka in Japan are the houses of the HAKOGI family and the FURUI family, both in Hyogo Prefecture, and they were already being called 'Sennenya' (a thousand year old house) in the Edo Period.

sen.j: 実際はさすがに千年は経っていないが、建立は室町時代にさかのぼるものと考えられている。
sen.e: Actually they are not a thousand year old, but they are considered old enough to be built in Muromachi Period.
Actually they are not a thousand years old, but they are considered old enough to have been built in the Muromachi Period.
In fact they are not a thousand years old, but they are considered old enough to have been built in the Muromachi Period.

sen.j: いずれも国の重要文化財。
sen.e: They are both designated as National Important Cultural Properties.
They are both designated as National Important Cultural Properties.
They are both designated as National Important Cultural Properties.

sen.j: 箱木家住宅（箱木千年家、兵庫県神戸市北区山田町）
sen.e: House of the HAKOI family (HAKOI Sennenya, Yamada Cho, Kita Ward, Kobe City, Hyogo Prefecture)
House of the HAKOI family (HAKOI Sennenya, Yamada Cho, Kita Ward, Kobe City, Hyogo Prefecture)
House of the HAKOGI family (HAKOGI Sennenya, Yamada Cho, Kita Ward, Kobe City, Hyogo Prefecture)

sen.j: 古井家住宅（古井千年家、兵庫県姫路市安富町）
sen.e: House of the FURUI family (FURUI Sennenya, Yasutomi Cho, Himeji City, Hyogo Prefecture)
House of the FURUI family (FURUI Sennenya, Yasutomi Cho, Himeji City, Hyogo Prefecture)
House of the FURUI family (FURUI Sennenya, Yasutomi Cho, Himeji City, Hyogo Prefecture)

sen.j: 江戸時代初期の民家は近畿地方を中心に多数残っている。
sen.e: Many minka from early Edo Period have survived mainly in Kinki region.
Many minka from the early Edo Period have survived, mainly in the Kinki region.
Many minka from the early Edo Period have survived, mainly in the Kinki region.

sen.j: 中でも、第二次大戦以前に民家として初めて（旧）国宝に指定された次の2件の民家が知られている。
sen.e: The following two houses are known to be designated as (former) National Treasure as minka before the Second World War:
The following two houses are known to have been designated as (former) National Treasures as minka before the Second World War:
The following two houses are known to have been designated as (former) National Treasures as minka before the Second World War:

sen.j: （1950年の文化財保護法施行後はいずれも重要文化財）。
sen.e: (They are both Important Cultural Properties after the enactment of the Law for the Protection of Cultural Properties in 1950.)
(They are both now Important Cultural Properties following the enactment of the Law for the Protection of Cultural Properties in 1950.)
(They are both now Important Cultural Properties following the enactment of the Law for the Protection of Cultural Properties in 1950.)

sen.j: 吉村家住宅（大阪府羽曳野市） - 1937年重要文化財（旧国宝）指定
sen.e: House of the YOSHIMURA family (Habikino City, Osaka Prefecture): being designated as Important Cultural Property (former National Treasure) in 1937.
House of the YOSHIMURA family (Habikino City, Osaka Prefecture): being designated as an Important Cultural Property (former National Treasure) in 1937.
sen.cmt: This conflicts with the previous sentence. Did it become an Important Cultural Property in 1937 or 1950?
sen.e: House of the YOSHIMURA family (Habikino City, Osaka Prefecture): being designated as an Important Cultural Property (former National Treasure) in 1937.

sen.j: 小川家住宅（二条陣屋）（京都府京都市） - 1944年重要文化財（旧国宝）指定
sen.e: House of the OGAWA family ("Nijo-jinya") (Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture): being designated as Important Cultural Property (former National Treasure) in 1944.
House of the OGAWA family ("Nijo-jinya") (Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture): being designated as an Important Cultural Property (former National Treasure) in 1944.
House of the OGAWA family (Nijo-jinya) (Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture): being designated as an Important Cultural Property (former National Treasure) in 1944.

sen.j: 一般に近畿地方方面が経済的先進地域であり、民家にも技術的、意匠的に優れたものが多い。
sen.e: Since Kinki region had been economically developed earlier in those days, there are many minka that were technologically advanced with excellent designs.
Since the Kinki region historically used to be more economically developed than other areas of Japan, there are many minka that were technologically advanced with excellent designs.
sen.cmt: The term 'those days' is a little unclear.
sen.e: Since the Kinki region historically used to be more economically developed than other areas of Japan, there are many minka that were technologically advanced with excellent designs.

sen.j: 関東地方では韮山代官、江川太郎左衛門の屋敷として有名な次のものがある（重要文化財）。
sen.e: In Kanto region, the following minka, residence of Tarozaemon EGAWA, Daikan of Nirayama, is famous:
In the Kanto region, the following minka, residence of Tarozaemon EGAWA, Daikan of Nirayama, is famous:
In the Kanto region, the following minka, residence of Tarozaemon EGAWA, Daikan (local governor) of Nirayama, is famous:

sen.j: 江川家住宅、韮山役所（伊豆の国市） 一部に中世の部材も使われているという。
sen.e: House of the EGAWA family, Nirayama yakusho (Izunokuni City); part of its constructiion materials are said to be from the medieval times.
House of the EGAWA family, Nirayama yakusho (Izunokuni City); part of its construction materials are said to be from medieval times.
House of the EGAWA family, Nirayama yakusho (government office) (Izunokuni City); part of its construction materials are said to be from medieval times.

sen.j: ごく古い民家では、柱をかんなで仕上げず、ちょうなで削ったままのものも見られる。
sen.e: Wooden columns only roughly whittled with chona, without finishing with a plane, were used for some of very old minka.
Some very old minka had wooden columns roughtly whittled with chona (a hooked wooden tool with a metal blade used to shape wood), and were not finished with a plane.
sen.cmt: 再構成しました. It would be interesting for the reader to understand what a chona is perhaps.
sen.e: Some very old minka had wooden columns roughly whittled with chona (a hooked wooden tool with a metal blade used to shape wood), and were not finished with a plane.

sen.j: また、古いものほど概して軒高が低く、壁や柱が多く閉鎖的な印象を受けるものが多い。
sen.e: The older they are, the lower eaves, and the more walls and columns they have, giving impression of isolation.
The older they are, the lower the eaves, and the more walls and columns they have, giving an impression of isolation.
The older they are, the lower the eaves, and the more walls and columns they have, giving an impression of isolation.

sen.j: 床の間、障子戸などに細かな細工を施すのは比較的新しい時代の現象で、古い民家は素朴なものが多い。
sen.e: Relatively new houses are equipped with elaborately worked wooden parts in tokonoma and shoji doors, while old minka are simple and rustic.
Relatively new houses are equipped with elaborately worked wooden parts such as tokonoma and shoji doors, whereas old minka are simple and rustic.
Relatively new houses are equipped with elaborately worked wooden parts such as tokonoma and shoji doors, whereas old minka are simple and rustic.

sen.j: 農家
sen.e: Noka (farm house)
Noka (farm houses)
Noka (farm houses)

sen.j: 屋内に土間があり、田の字型の間取りとしたものが典型的なものである。
sen.e: There is a dirt floor called doma inside, and squarely arranged four rooms is the most common room arrangement.
There is a dirt floor called a doma inside, and four squarely arranged rooms is the most common arrangement.
There is a dirt floor called a doma inside, and four squarely arranged rooms is the most common arrangement.

sen.j: 土間には煮炊きをする竃があり、馬屋もよく見られる。
sen.e: Doma is equipped with a clay oven called kamado for cooking, and is often attached with a stable.
The doma is equipped with a clay oven called a kamado for cooking, and often has a stable attached.
sen.cmt: Is the doma a room with a dirt floor, or the floor only? If it is only the floor we should change 'The doma is equipped with' to 'On the doma is' I think.
sen.e: The doma is equipped with a clay oven called a kamado for cooking, and often has a stable attached.

sen.j: いろりの周りで家長を中心に食事を取る。
sen.e: Family members gather around irori or a hearth to have meals with the family head on one side of it.
Family members gather around an irori or hearth to have meals, with the family head seated on one side of it.
Family members gather around an irori or hearth to have meals, with the family head seated on one side.
sen.cmt: “on one side of it.” => “on one side.”

sen.j: 時代が下がると接客用の部屋も造られ、冠婚葬祭で人が多く集まる際は、戸や襖を開け放して部屋を広く使えるように工夫された。
sen.e: In more recent years, a room was added to serve guests, and fusuma doors and other partitions were being removed to make a large single room for many people at events such as weddings, festivals, funerals, and other ceremonies.

In more recent years, a room was added to serve guests, and fusuma doors and other partitions were removed to make a large single room for many people at events such as weddings, festivals, funerals, and other ceremonies.

In more recent years, a room was added to serve guests, and fusuma doors and other partitions were removed to make a large single room for many people at events such as weddings, festivals, funerals, and other ceremonies.

sen.j: 土間で縄をなったり、縁側で機織をしたり、屋根裏でカイコを飼うなど、住居と生業の結びつきが強い。
sen.e: Minka and work were closely connected: doma was used also to make ropes; engawa or a veranda for weaving; and silkworms were raised on the attic room.
Minka and work were closely connected: doma were used also to make ropes; the engawa or veranda for weaving; and silkworms were raised in the attic.
Minka and work were closely connected: doma were used also to make ropes; the engawa or veranda for weaving; and silkworms were raised in the attic.

sen.j: 茅葺や杉皮、瓦など屋根材も地域によって特徴が見られる。
sen.e: Materials for roofing, such as thatch, cedar bark, and tiles, were different region to region.
Materials for roofing, such as thatch, cedar bark, and tiles, were different region to region.
Materials for roofing, such as thatch, cedar bark, and tiles, were different region to region.

sen.j: 町家
sen.e: Machiya (town house)
Machiya (town houses)
Machiya (town houses)

sen.j: 間口が狭く、奥行きがあり、裏まで通り抜けの通路が設けられることが多い。
sen.e: Machiya is small in width at the entrance and long in depth, often with a path running through from the front of the house to the back.
Machiya are small in width at the entrance and long in depth, often with a passage running through from the front of the house to the back.
sen.cmt: Path' gives the impression of not having walls.
sen.e: Machiya are small in width at the entrance and long in depth, often with a passage running through from the front of the house to the back.

sen.j: 間口が狭いのは、間口の大きさに応じて税金をかけていた名残だといい、道路に面して短冊形に敷地を取るタイプが各地に見られる。
sen.e: A reason for its small width is said to have come from those days when tax was imposed in accordance with the storefront width, and strip-shaped premises with the short side on the street are commonly seen in many regions.

A reason for its small width is said to have come from the days when tax was imposed in accordance with the width of the entrance, and strip-shaped premises with the short side on the street are commonly seen in many regions.

A reason for its small width is said to have come from the days when tax was imposed in accordance with the width of the entrance, and strip-shaped premises with the short side on the street are commonly seen in many regions.

sen.j: 道路に面した表側は店になっており、裏の方に住まいや蔵などを設けた。
sen.e: The room on the street was used as a shop, and the redidence area and a storehouse were on the back.
The room on the street was used as a shop, and the residence area and a storehouse were at the back.
The room on the street was used as a shop, and the residence area and a storehouse were at the back.

sen.j: 京都などの町家に見られる坪庭は、通風・採光の役割を果している。
sen.e: Tsuboniwa (a tiny garden) as seen in machiya in Kyoto functions as ventilation and lighting.
The tsuboniwa (a tiny garden) as seen in machiya in Kyoto facilitated ventilation and lighting.
The tsuboniwa (a tiny garden) as seen in machiya in Kyoto facilitated ventilation and lighting.

sen.j: 第二次世界大戦後、特に高度成長期以降は、日本人の生活スタイルも大きく変化した。
sen.e: Lifestyles of Japanese people have greatly changed since the Second World War, especially since the period of rapid economic growth.
The lifestyles of Japanese people have greatly changed since the Second World War, especially as a result of the ensuing period of rapid economic growth.
The lifestyles of Japanese people have greatly changed since the Second World War, especially as a result of the ensuing period of rapid economic growth.

sen.j: 伝統的な生活文化を後世に残すため、民家を移築復元した民家園などが各地に作られるようになった。
sen.e: Minka parks where minka were transferred and restored were costructed in many places to pass traditional Japanese culture down the generations.
Minka parks where minka were transferred to and restored were constructed in many places in order to pass traditional Japanese culture down the generations.
Minka parks where minka were transferred to and restored were constructed in many places in order to pass traditional Japanese culture down the generations.

sen.j: 古い民家を保存、公開することで、歴史を学ぶ史料としている。
sen.e: Old minka are preserved and open to the public as materials to study history.
Old minka are preserved and open to the public as materials to study history.
Old minka are preserved and open to the public as materials to study history.

sen.j: 単に建物を公開するだけでなく、当時の民具を展示したり、いろりに火をくべたり、伝統行事を再現するなど、より生活感を表し、来場者が身近に感じられるよう工夫をこらしている施設も多くなってきた。
sen.e: In many facilities today, they not only show the houses, but are trying to let visitors experience lives of old days, such as displaying old articles of everyday use, lighting a real irori, and reproducing traditional events.

In many facilities today, they not only show the houses, but try to let visitors experience the lifestyle of the old days, such as by displaying contemporary articles of everyday use, lighting real irori, and reenacting traditional events.

In many facilities today, they not only show the houses, but try to let visitors experience the lifestyle of the old days, such as by displaying contemporary articles of everyday use, lighting real irori, and reenacting traditional events.

sen.j: 東日本
sen.e: Eastern Japan
Eastern Japan
Eastern Japan

sen.j: 草を植えた棟（青森県）
sen.e: Kusa-wo-uetamune (Aomori Prefecture)
Kusa-wo-uetamune (Aomori Prefecture)

sen.e: Magariya (Iwate Prefecture)

sen.e: Chumonzukuri (Akita Prefecture)

sen.e: Chumonzukuri (Nigata Prefecture)

sen.j: 本棟造（長野県）
sen.e: Honmunezukuri (Nagano Prefecture)

Honmune-zukuri (Nagano Prefecture)

sen.j: つきあげ屋根（山梨県）
sen.e: Tsukiageyane (Yamanashi Prefecture)
Tsukiageyane (Yamanashi Prefecture)
Tsukiageyane (Yamanashi Prefecture)

sen.j: 赤城棟（群馬県）
sen.e: Akagimune (Gunma Prefecture)
Akagimune (Gunma Prefecture)

sen.j: 入母屋（埼玉県）
